Reviews.Title: Samsung Solstice
Reviews.Author: kay
Reviews.Content: I had this phone before and I loved it that's the reason I was buying a replacement phone for my daughter because her phone was stolen. When I received the phone it was in the original packaging from the company but when I turn on the phone there were text messages , stored contact numbers and a alarm that was already set from the previous owner. That was it for me I return the phone and got a refund because I don't like being lied to the phone was listed as "New" not "Used" if I wanted to buy a used phone I would have. I would never buy anything from this company again because I can't trust them this was misleading and cost me an extra $4.50 to return the phone.

Reviews.Title: Samsung Solstice
Reviews.Author: Eilrahc Alleba "Charlie"
Reviews.Content: Bought it for my wife and was so glad to have it. The service is good (awesome seller), as it arrived on time or was earlier than expected, and was packed really well. The phone itself functions perfectly for texting and talking, considering it's low price...Since it's a quad-band, I can use it outside the USA...I will buy from this seller again...I had it as advertised...Unbelievable find!  Thanks!!!

Reviews.Title: Good alternative to a standard cell phone!
Reviews.Author: Buckland
Reviews.Content: For my purposes, the Samsung A887 Solstice fills the bill.  It’s better, slicker, than a run-of-the-mill barebones cell phone.  While it can access the Internet, the browsing is quite cumbersome.  Also, unlike later “smartphones,” your access to the Internet is strictly through your cellular service (in my case Consumer Cellular); there is no Wi-Fi capability for charge-free access at home or any “hot spots” on the road.But I did not purchase the phone with the expectation of surfing the web.  I do that with my laptop computer, which I carry with me when I travel.  Besides, even if I did need to look for lodging, locate restaurants, gas stations, etc. while between Point A and Point B…well, my wife’s true smart phone is perfectly capable of that (hers is a Samsung Galaxy Exhilarate, with Wi-Fi and all the bells’n whistles).Essentially, I only need a cell phone as we are getting rid of our land line.  My wife has a smart phone, I have a dumb phone.  Primarily, I use my phone for, well “phone calls (and the fewer the better).  While the A887 sports a virtual “Qwerty” keypad (far less cumbersome than texting with a plain old cell phone numerical pad), I’m not really into texting that much…but I could.The 2 megapixel onboard camera (front-facing only) is decent.  My wife’s 5 megapixel camera is somewhat better—more than adequate for posting on Facebook.  But I’m too much of a cynical old perfectionist to rely on a phone camera in lieu of a separate digital camera.  [Ironically, I was into the hi-tech age early.  I owned my first PC in 1988, at a time when friends and relatives scoffed at the notion of online communication.]I have yet to explore all of the bells and whistles—such as setting ringtones, etc.—but the speakerphone is crisp and clear, which is important to me; I simply hate holding a device up to my ear for more than about 120 seconds.Given that I do not live my life staring at a small screen while in the company of friends (believe it or not, I have a couple), or riding the rails, or should be on an actual vacation, this unobtrusive little gadget is the right choice for me (small brain, small phone).  It is slim and smaller all the way around than your standard iPhones and “Droids” that you see around today.  Takes up little space and is comfortable enough to carry around in my pants pocket (when I don’t forget to carry it, that is).Bottom line:  For around 50 bucks, you’d be hard-pressed to find a better standard cell phone equivalent.  You can text, add photo attachments to your text and access the Internet, if you need to.  My wife and I have two separate lines and use our phones, sharing our minutes and data via Consumer Cellular (AT&T; backbone), for a paltry sum of 40 bucks per month.We are happy.
